regretList.regret: I regret not taking my music more seriously and truly learning that skill and to compose.

I regret not taking an opportunity that was presented to me by my Aunt because I thought I wasn’t good enough or experienced enough. It was an internship so looking back now, it didn’t matter how much experience I had to start, I would have been learning.
Letting the worry of what others think determine my career path.
I regret trying to make myself look good to a new boss, it backfired and I always felt I was better than that
Not realizing my infinite potential and not having enough self confidence to do more when I was younger
Not being more understanding of my parents and their troubles when I was a child.
Changed job due to money offered, however money brought wealth, life became boring and stressful.
Spent more time trying to understand my most difficult child and really listening.
Not saving more money earlier.

Not studying harder in school and focusing too much on trying to get laid as a teen which led to doing things to "look cool" such as drinking alcohol and smoking cigarettes and partying because I thought I needed sex more than anything.
I regret getting married to my spouse. I didn't know the extent of my spouse's anxiety and the impact it would have on our lives.
I regret not going back to school to get an advanced degree.
Premarital sex

My most significant regret is not getting a graduate degree before diving into my career. I want to change careers now but I don’t have the requisite degree and have a young family so I can’t afford to go back to school.
I regret the times I didn’t think I was as good as my peers, and that I had zero awareness of what skills I had to offer because I wasn’t the same as the image they “all” put on.
My children are both handicapped with autism and will never be able to live on their own. The second is my career never got to where it seemed to be going.
Not clearing the most important exam of my life
Took things too personally. Spent too much time in my head and not enough noticing life around me.
Not keeping in touch with a potential life partner
not helping my family more and then failing to finish my phd so it was a lose, lose situation.
I regret not seeking mental health care sooner.
I wish I had been more present and communicated better in my last relationship.
I was too boy-crazy as an adolescent and teenager. Although I did well academically, my focus was on boys and popularity to an excessive extent.
That I never learned to like any sort of exercise
I regret not being more present for my siblings when they were growing up and I was a self-absorbed teenager.

I regret not building a business based on my work earlier in life. I've spent 15 years growing online businesses for other people and affiliate to their products. If I could have done it all over I would have seen the value in my work more than I relied on what others created. I'm changing this now but it has weighed on me!

I regret that I didn't challenge my conditioning and fears earlier in life. I wouldn't have taken such safe bets - not with the courage & skills I have and communities I've built. I could've gone on adventures that would've been in line with my values.
I wish I would have managed my investors money well.
No regrets
when I was in high school, I lied all the time,  about anything and everything. Now I live in fear of my lies being found out, and I wish I had just been more truthful.
One regret is I didn’t take a proper degree which was needed chose a easy distance education.
I wish I had better defined goals when I was younger (e.g. career) and the confidence to pursue them. Instead, I look back and see many important decisions I made were merely reactions.
I don’t have any significant regrets.
Not spending more time talking to and getting to know other students when I was in college and law school.
I regret not baking my father enough baked goods.
test this thing.
That I meet many wonderful individuals and never stayed in touch.
Having sex when I was too young including getting married too young instead of going to college.

I regret I did not make a more loving and safe home for my children.  They didn't grow up afraid or hungry or scared, I was working and just didn't always spend the quality time with them they needed.
On my first date with my ex husband I said it was okay for him to smoke pot. I should have ended it and not gone on a second date. I knew our values weren't in alignment but married him anyway.
Not having finished college and not saving more of my inheritance
Not doing a semester (or summer) abroad.
My biggest regret is that I didn’t dig and push harder to get more details about my parents’ and grandparents’ lives and experiences.
Not recording my kids early days
I regret I didn't go to Uncle Bobby's funeral
Not learning how to play an instrument
I regret not pursuing a professional basketball career. I should have worked more on my post moves and made the league.
I regret not going to my first choice college. It would have introduced me to more life experiences.
Not taking a job in Scotland when I graduated from college.  I wanted to stay in the US to be near friends.

I was named after a family member who died young and therefore it became a superstitious belief of mine from an early age that I also would die young. I tried very hard to do things I enjoyed, have good relationships, and not worry too much. At each moment I trust I did the best with the knowledge and resources I had, and I really can’t think of any regrets yet.

1. I regret not finding a sport, activity or club to be a part of during high school. This would've kept me engaged and out of idle trouble. 
2. I regret not focusing on me and my future by not going to college. My life would be completely different today.
In 10th grade not explaining to a girlfriend what did/not happen
Not learning to love myself
Missing my kids activities while they were growing up due to work.
Picking the “easy” degree to obtain in college even though I didn’t love it. Becoming a SAHM to 3 kids dt circumstances, making me totally uncompetitive now in the workforce.

I regret not taking the time to go on a student exchange program right after college. Instead, I chose a stable job. That job led to a successful career today, but I still wish I took a chance back then and travel, discover the world.
Letting myself gain weight. Letting go of relationships from my youth
Retiring early because I hated working with my new boss
I regret not spending more time with my mother in law when she was dying from cancer.
Not spending more time with my grandma when I went to visit last year.
different career path than my family wanted for me but I didn't have enough confidence at the time or high level skills
Hanging on to my resentment of my parents for many years

A lifelong stoic and introvert who's not big on asking questions, I regret not speaking up which had I done so may have had a positive effect on my marriage that sadly ended in divorce after 32 years, my career which was modest at best, my relationships with family and friends which tend to be one sided, and my overall quality of life.

I regret not helping my mom when she discovered she had cancer.
I regret not giving more fucks.
I regret not focusing more on myself.
I regret not trying harder to have a relationship with my father.
I regret not trying harder to keep in touch with close friends.
I regret that people I love have died.
I did not pursue my first love (theatre) out of fear of starving and rejection.
Picking a different law school
Those times I couldn't find a positive in a tough situation. I made too many "surface" decisions.
I wish I had taken a gap year or a working holiday in the UK like many other Australians.

Marrying and having children when i did.  I didn't know enough about the world, love, other people, etc. (only minor things) at the time.  Whilst people obviously change, and there is a need work and change with them and the new relationships, i feel like it was a major decision that i didn't fully understand enough about to make a good one.  I know that sounds bad...!
Not fixing my body post-injury sooner. Could've had so many awesome memories and great experiences playing all around the world if I had.
Not honouring my self - allowing others needs to matter more than my own
I regret that i got involved in someone else's private matters

When I was in upper elementary school, my friend and I auditioned for the school pop group. Naively, I think we assumed that both of us would be selected, or neither of us would be. Only 3-4 students were chosen to represent the hundreds on the school roll. I should have been thrilled when my name was announced, but my friend missed out, and, such was her influence and control, I felt compelled to decline. The music teacher contacted my parents and all three spent days imploring me to reconsider. I stubbornly refused. On the night of the performance, I regretted not being up on stage - the group appeared to be having so much fun. But the greater regret, the part that has stayed with me all my life, has been knowing that I didn’t take the chance that came my way because I succumbed to pressure from a person who felt no joy over my achievement; only bitterness as a result of her own disappointment. I’ve always been grateful for the lesson, but the choice I made remains a deep regret.
Listening to someone say I cannot dance and then giving it up.
- Not completing my PMP certification.
Worrying too much about How I look and what others think of me that it hindered me from really living my full potential and doing and being what makes me most happy.
I regret many discussions with muy father, i was just a kid that needed to fight. Nowadays i would rather fight against many injustices of the world.
I wasn't "there" for my grandmother at the end of her life. I nursed petty grievances; I blew it.
I regret not having been a better, kinder, more patient parent.
I didn't study more

I regret forgoing my values in order to get ahead in my career. As someone who believes in living with integrity, to be involved in a political career at a high level caused me to slowly and nearly imperceptibly step away from my morals on a daily basis. At the end of that job, I had become someone I didn’t recognize, that my family didn’t like and had lost more than a job... I lost my identity.
Moving in with a boyfriend at the age of 19. I wish I would have experienced living on my own instead
Not being mindful of my young son’s turtle, Freddie, who died from neglect.
I regret I didn’t speak more with my mother when she was sick before she died.
I wish i had gone to law school
I regret not continuing learning to play the violin or piano
Not speaking up to ask my Dad for help when I was 13. I was depressed and anxious from years of bullying and emotional abuse (and neglect, within our own family).
Not taking opportunities to study or teach abroad after college
Not taking learning seriously in high school.
Ever dieting. Once you start that cycle you are onto a losing journey forever.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Travelling down the road of regret can be a dangerous practice if not conducted with objectivity. Because even as I look back on what I might consider a regret, was actually lots of situations largely outside my control. It’s only I’m in my thirties that I see the opportunities and finding the bravery to decide. Looking forward, I don’t want to regret choosing not to choose with intention.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not telling people that they have upset me and what they have done to upset me

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not being more confident

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not going to uni to develop myself and my learning

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not taking my college education more seriously.
Not fully appreciating a relationship with an ex-girlfriend. The relationship was over before I fully appreciated what I had.

Not telling Adam Anderson that I still loved him and couldn’t imagine my life without him. I was barely putting my life without him together when he came back, asking for another chance to try again. I should have said, I love you, yes let’s try again. It’s been 18 years and my biggest regret.
I regret marrying young and for the wrong reasons. We have been married for 19 years, but my spouse would’ve been happier with someone else.
study another language
I regret not getting my Masters degree when I was young and at 53 I still could do it buy still haven’t so I regret that too.

I wish I had stayed in the room during my father's final hours of life. I was stressed, exhausted, and believed at the time I was supposed to take care of my wailing step-mother. I should have stayed by his side until the end. That's the biggest regret of my life.
regret wasting time, years, not getting over a fail relationship or man
I regret wishing the present, the moment, away. I always wanted more than I had.
Not being more awake to the opportunities I had available to me in my earlier career. Lack of self awareness.
I wish I hadn't gotten pregnant at nineteen.
That I didn't take enough business classes as an undergrad. Got my MBA 15 years later, but it would have helped if I know finance way earlier.
Staying in a bad, emotionally abusive relationship too long

I regret not spending more time with my grandmother. She was a child during the great depression, lost a young brother when his foot got stuck in a railroad track, got divorced before it was considered acceptable, fought off a purse snatcher by beating him up, and made a living making blankets, stuffed animals and toys. I wish I'd listened to her stories and learned her craft. I didn't realize it when I was kid but now I understand what a strong woman she was.
Not really living up to the love I used to get (and really still do) by my mother
I regret not coming back with him on that night. There was never an opportunity to do that again, and there never will be.
Not stayed in NY with my ex
I regret not maximizing my oportunities instead of just doing the average (i.e. not studying really really hard at College).
Not taking the time to let people know how much I loved them before they passed away.

My youngest son died at 3 years old and we donated his organs... before he was taken to the operating room we had a ceremony at the hospital with family and friends and after that we left. I regret not having walked by his body to the limits of the operating room. I was still in a certain amount of shock so I am not angry at myself but if I could go back I would walk with him...
I regret studying in science because people told me I was good at it and that it was a good job instead of studying in communication or psychology.

I went to New Zealand for an MBA for two years. I was offered a job and decided to stay for an extra year or two.  I loved the lifestyle and it seems a place where creative people who do not in other countries can find a place.  But...I decided to move to Australian and then back to Canada.  My regret? It took a while to figure the out but leaving NZ is my biggest regret.  While Canada is home, it does not feel like home.  I feel lije a foreigner here now. I have skills, expertise and a way of thinking that is not that welcome here.
Not enjoying my teenage years more. I was depressed, anxious, and angry all the time. I wish I had appreciated my life and my parents more.
Micromanaging an experience with my son when he was in 5th grade.
I regret not serving in the military, but it’s not a large regret.
Majoring in Psychology instead of Math. Following the foolish advice to do what you love instead of what your good at.

I regret not traveling abroad more during college/mid 20’s.  As a student athlete my schedule didn’t allow for it and when I started working I didn’t feel I had enough cash in the bank to splurge.  Now, in my mid-30s, with kids in the future and a rampant pandemic, I’m afraid I won’t ever be able to make the time or even have a chance to do so.
I regret not taking my injury more seriously.
I regret not taking my parents’ advice on pursuing a bankable career. If I’d become a doctor or a lawyer, I wouldn’t have a problem looking for work or a stable source of incom

I don’t think it’s regrettable?  I got pregnant, and then married. My husband.  I love my family- but have wondered how life would be different with a different partner. I am also grateful for this decision too.
Staying in a marriage
I didn’t vote for my sibling for high school class president because no other hands were raised for her (they should have had a ballot).  As it was high school, it was more of a popularity contest.

I changed my carrier from a scientist to a business consultant and executive. I regret it, as the causes of my decision were not valid. I didn' perceived the changes in my surroundings and in my state, so it was a wrong decision.
Egyik vezetői döntésemet sajnálom.
Less work as a guide,less social connection,more to do at home: to study with my kids+ working in home office+ home work,as a single mother more stress.
Too early marriage.

to cheat on my husband
not being conscious in my ealry career
Not having children of my own.
I got impatient with my company in Oregon and moved my family to Tennessee.  The grass is always greener on the other side.

I regret believing in what I was “supposed to” be and do. No adult in my family allowed me to think for myself, to have my own perspective, ideas about what I wanted to be/do. I wasted a lot of time trying to fit in, to live up to others’ judgmental biases and never feeling like I was enough. I know better now, but I regret that I took so long to figure it out and have an almost O.D.D. kneejerk reaction to “supposed to’s” today - fiercely protective of my independence as if my life literally depends on it.
Not being my grandmother's friend and really getting to know her while she was alive..
I regret that it took me so long to end an unsuitable dating relationship.

Not going to Harvard 
not having more children
Voicing an ugly statement and belittling someone during times of pressure which was far removed from my values.
I regret to not have spoken my opinions more loudly in the past...I thought that the once older knew better, but I was wrong!

Not having children earlier.
Not investing my time better early on in my career.
That I wasnt nicer to a boy that liked me
I regret that I spent so much time worrying about things that may have happened.
I regret not having had enough confidence in high school to work harder when I tried out for the lead in a musical. I was chosen to be the understudy.
Not going to college for what I really wanted to do instead of going for something my parent wanted me to take in college
Regret not applying myself to get better grades in high school and continuing my education beyond my bachelor’s degree.
I regret worrying about what others think of me.  Time wasted.
Not taking more chances and risks
I regret leaving a decent career to go into entrepreneurship. Almost 5 years later and I'm earning the least amount of money I ever have in my career of around 17 years.
When I was a teenager, I made a series of bad choices. Those choices caused others to follow my leadership. It cost them many years of hardship.
At times, I regret not applying to Princeton for college. I stayed with relatively safe schools. However, I know that where I went to college was the best place for me and led me to where I am today.

I regret not going to a college that was recommended to me by my wonderful librarian in high school. The school was an arts focused, work to earn your tuition college in Kentucky. Instead I chose the same college as all my friends at the time. I will always wonder how my life would’ve been different. He was right.
I regret not learning self confidence earlier.
I regret that I did not pursue my life’s dream aggressively.  I was afraid I would fail.
I regret how I handled the planning and execution of my wedding because I wa ask angry my sister was pregnant and due the same week.
Not moving to a different location from where I grew up.
Not speaking up sooner. Not suggesting solutions as often as I complained about something. Not recording and exposing more.
I regret not telling her that I love her.

Not saving more for retirement.
Time wasted on someone undeserving of my affection
I did not take risks to invest, leave bad relationships, to save money. I worried every day.
Not changing companies several years ago. I have been at the same company for 27 years now and although they are good to me it would have been beneficial to get other perspectives.
Not talking more with my parents about their lives.
I said yes when I meant no. More than once. And failed to hold hard and fast to standards of behavior in my love life that never should have been stretched. I'll always regret those choices.

I regret not doing a semester or a year abroad when I was in college.  I wish I had the language fluency, life experiences, and memories that truly *living* abroad would have given me.  I'm 51 years old now - and I still hope to remedy this regret before my time on this planet is up.  Actually, "hope" is not a sufficiently intentional word.  I *plan* to remedy this regret before my time on this planet is up.  Looking at my answer staring back at me from my computer screen right now, I also realize that - although I still feel reasonably young at 51 - I'm not guaranteed unlimited time to fix this.  I need to get on this sooner rather than later.  [Scrambles off to begin planning...]
Not spending time with my grandparents when I could before they died
Not knowing my son's mother better.
Listen to my husband when I knew I shouldn't have. Just to make him feel more like a man.
I regret worry about things that didn’t matter and being over reactive as opposed to grateful.

I regret waiting so long to have children (conceiving in my mid-late 30s when I I wish I’d started in my late 20s for physical reasons).

Also regret I didn’t practice saying no sooner in my life / standing up for myself, even with family.
Not being able to leave home for university
I wish I had laughed more.
Not starting my financial independence journey earlier
As a child I was sick on the day the football team was picked so I missed being selected. I couldn’t get on the team after that.

I regret for not taking school serious, study more and read more while I have the leisure time. I’m at my 30’s, still not too late but it would’ve been a head start if I were to be more responsible in my early life. 

I regret for not making good friends and maintaining the friendship that I could cherish today.
I would have liked to date more before getting married. I should have cared less about other people’s opinions when I was a teenager.
Not to help someone that could be very easy
I regret not being mature enough to give my best while in college.
I regret not paying off my debts when I had the money.
Spend more time of quality, enjoying the moment with my family, people who I care, friends and of course, family members and pets (dogs) that have passed away.
Not supporting my son in his choice of girlfriend
My partner did not want to have children. I did, we split up, but came together again as I gave in. Now, 25 years later, I regret not having children.

Not going to Paris as an au pair, because I was (last minute) admitted to the school of my choice. I could have studied a year later, but I missed an important possibility to be in Paris for a year, learn French fluently and get some important life experiences. I was too responsible.
Not making relationship decisions easier, wasting time with struggling

Went back to an old PR agency to become MD and left a well-paid gig in a huge tech company. Boss wasn't upfront about revenue situation so I got fired. My six months was a back-breaking thankless nightmare. That was five years ago. Went into depression. Haven't recovered since.
I regret not saving money early in my working life.
unfaithfulness
Actually I dont like to regret and I believe that everything is happened in my life for my best future.
I married a woman, had a child and she completely changed.  Any love was gone. Wish I had divorced her earlier.
I regret cheating on Rae.

I regret not prioritizing family. I believed the doctor’s opinion on a fertility issue and after 4 miscarriages, we stopped trying. I wonder what our life would be like if we had ever had children together.
Teacher taught me and I listened, took notes and remembered for the test.
launch own firm at pretty bad timing on Mar.10 2011
Due to a tragedy in my childhood I still cannot forgive my mother and not am connected With my family

I wish I had joined a band when I was invited by a boys band when I was a teenage girl in 80s. I was too shy and not confident despite 8 years organ experience..the life with music and good friends may have changed my life.
Not pushing myself beyond my expectations or assumptions of old myself. I felt that there are tons of opportunities
Getting married too young
I have impulsively made choices towards gratification rather than staying the course. Life has been interesting but uncertain.
Not looking after my health through the years. I did lots to hurt my health and not much to help it. Also, I did not save for my retirement and now I'm 62 unhealthy and broke.
The way I treated relationships as a teenager
Letting other people tell me what I want.
How I have treated others, when I wasn’t living up to my own standards.

Having an abortion when I was 20. It did not align to my values. I let the views of society persuade me it was okay to do this. I could not hide from God what I had done. I believe God forgave me through the cross but I had a terrible time forgiving myself. It changed the course of my life and I still hide what I did from people I love so they won’t reject me.
Regret not saving more money earlier in my life.  Regret spending time and energy worrying about what others think of me.
Completed college at a younger age
I regret not studying abroad in college.
Taking debt to run my former company.
That I didn't fulfill my dream of studying architecture.
Not being more present and involved with my children and their hobbies/interests when they were younger. I mean, I was involved, but I could have been more involved.
Built a house
Not recognizing that the schools in my town were not meeting my children’s needs and my expectations. I should have cut bait with them a long time ago.
not being 'adult' earlier
I made a shit ton of excuses to lie to myself about my lack of affection for someone while I really have feelings for that person
my life is a story of regrets
Obeing my society unnecessary restricting rules during my teen years ,expressing myself confidently (physically and mentally) , and caring what people thinks about me
Not following enough what really makes me happy, instead of trying to make others happy or proud of me.

I regret always perceiving myself as fat when in reality I was slim and beautiful. This has led to years of trying to lose weight. 
Now when I have gained too much weight, my body no longer responds to any attempts. I have now come terms with the way I look and live with peace in my mind.
That I have to go to work for making a living
Wish i did’t leave my country when i was young. Have lived in three different countries and feel homeless.

Biggest regret ever: leaving my one true love 25 years ago, because I was too young back then to have the courage to stay in a foreign country without an education or job and not skilled enough in the local language to obtain either within a reasonable time period. Went back to my home country and got a great education and an even more fantastic job, but have not been able to find the right match thus leading to trying out the concept: if you cannot get the one you love, try to love the one you can get (which is a poor choice!)

That I decided to marry a woman I have been struggling to live with for almost seven years now just to please my aging parents who thought it would do them an honour to see me married before their retirement age. It feels like my real wife is also married somewhere else as I had to push her away for the woman I live with now...total regret that one
I regret not listening to my instincts earlier because it would save me from severe depression due to an abusive relationship.
I regret not investing time and energy in understandin my own emotions and human emotions in general, focusing too much on work and doing the right things, having a black or white approach.
I got married too soon after I met my husband. I should have taken more time for myself and be more brave to stand up my parents.
To get married too early
I had put too much pressure on my wife when we moved abroad for my new job. I should have quitted and went back home to my old job.
I did not participate in marching band in college.

Being truer to myself earlier. Not trying to just fit in and do what I “should” be doing. I wish I had figured that part earlier. I made a lot of smaller mistakes that turned into regrets because I wasn’t true to myself.
Hurted other people at emotional level.
The choice about my University degree . I followed my professor advise...
Keeping on a relationship
I seriously regret not learning more about the power of money, and the how to manage it better.

I regret that I did not know more about the time I grew up in while I was growing up in South Africa. Although I never mistreated any person of color, I never did anything to end Apartheid. However, I've been giving back for many years through the career I've chosen.
I wish I'd come out of the closet earlier in life. I feel coming out at 40 wasted many years of youth.
Taking my first husband back instead of letting him go
Not doing things - travel -  because i thought i had to establish a career first
I wish I'd had a deeper, closer relationship with my father.
Followed people’s advice and got married while I had my doubts and gut feeling maybe this is not what it should be.
Not having controled my anger / emotions over my mother’s illness (cancer) better before she died.
listened more and be more confident in myself.

I regret breaking off the contact to a friend I had a crush on ten years ago. At that time I thought I couldn’t handle the pain of a broken heart. Nowadays I regret my decisions because I’ve learned that crushes and heartaches go away and that friendships could last through those feelings.

Not spending more time with my grandmother, since I was studying in Germany and, everytime I flew back to Spain, I ended up spending more time with my friends and my girlfriend (at the time). I wished I had spent more quality time with her.

Standing up for myself more, setting clear boundaries for how to be treated regardless of how the other person reacts to the boundaries. Looking back  on the things I regret it’s always when I didn’t do the right thing, by me, family, friends, by people or the environment. Doing the next right thing is such a core value for me.
More effort into my sporting ability
not being a better/present parent for my first son

Looking back, all the regrets I had at the time have eventually become advantages. I can't think of a single thing that I would have done differently  except those that might have hurt others...but even those turned out better for the person hurt.
I wish I had been braver when I was younger, particularly around dating.
Lost the chance of doing what I love because I listen to my parent's advice to study, get PhD and have an ordinary life

I have a few- one is not telling someone that I had very strong feelings about that I loved them. I think it I had it might have changed the relationship that we had and maybe had a different outcome but I was afraid. 

The other regret I have is not exploring more options for college. I had a full ride opportunity and then decided against attending the college (sometimes I regret that too with my high amount of student loan debt.) While I ended up loving where I went to college, I always wonder what other experiences I might have had somewhere else instead of the safe option I chose. 

My final is just not living life. I've always felt like I needed to be safe and so didn't do somethings that now I wish I would have. 

I think regret is a lot of "what ifs" in life. I always wonder how things might have looked different if I had chosen something else.

My study choices 
Not spending enough time with grandparents

I regret not having children
I regret not having followed my father's health problems closely
Not having a second child
Trying to be in a relationship with my sons father. I never loved him but thought our son should have a chance to grow up in a home with both parents.
My greatest regret in life was not realizing how depressed my Dad was before he died by suicide.
I regret not hugging my family when they needed it and when I needed it.
I regret not getting to know my parents and grandparents better before they were dead.
I regret not spending more time enjoying my daughter. I worked, attended college, and raised her, but it seems as if I did not have time to simply enjoy being with her.
Not taking my health serious enough. Physically, mentally and spiritually.
Not taking care of myself as much as I took care of other.

Having allowed people to abuse me in the name of maintaining good relationship with extended family. 
Overworking to prove myself to authorities who never valued me.
Having allowed some bullies to have their way in the fear of an unforeseen danger if I speak up.

Break uk with a girlfriend
Accepted the wrong business deal
I regret when starting a family with 18y only, accumulating debts with spending too much money / living above what I earned. Not allowing us to live a more free live with less work.
First marriage
I regret being indecisive about my abusive ex-husband.

I regret not being more courageous in my teens and twenties while choosing the university I studied at (as well as the subject) and then my career path.
